keyTakeAways: Typhoon Halong, which struck Alaska, caused catastrophic flooding and storm surge, destroying 90% of homes in Kipnuk and leaving over one-third of homes uninhabitable in Kwigillingok.
Over 2,000 people were displaced and evacuated, with some airlifted to Anchorage by military planes, primarily due to the inaccessibility of remote villages via road or land transport.
The storm surge, equivalent in strength to a Category 2 hurricane, resulted in one death, two missing persons, and widespread destruction in low-lying Arctic communities.
Alaska Governor Mike Dunleavy requested a major disaster declaration from the White House to secure federal aid for emergency and long-term recovery, including infrastructure and housing.
Evacuees are being housed in shelters such as schools, sports arenas, and convention centers in Anchorage, with some planning to permanently relocate and seek employment in urban settings.
Alaska's congressional delegation urged President Donald Trump to quickly approve the major disaster declaration to support relief efforts.
Residents like Alexie Stone and State Rep. Nellie Unangiq Jimmie described the trauma and uncertainty of displacement, emphasizing emotional and cultural loss in the face of environmental disaster.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A powerful storm, identified as Typhoon Halong, struck remote Alaska villages, causing catastrophic flooding and destroying nearly 90% of homes in Kipnuk and leaving over one-third of homes uninhabitable in Kwigillingok. Over 2,000 residents were displaced, with many evacuated to Anchorage via military planes. Governor Mike Dunleavy stated that due to the severity of the damage and Alaska’s harsh Arctic climate, many evacuees will not return home for at least 18 months. The federal government is being requested to declare a major disaster to provide aid, including emergency and permanent housing and infrastructure repairs. Personal accounts from evacuees like Alexie Stone and state representative Nellie Unangiq Jimmie highlight the emotional and cultural disruption of displacement, while Anchorage leaders emphasize their commitment to supporting the affected communities.
title: Alaska storm damage so bad many evacuees won’t go home for at least 18 months, governor says
